locuaz.amberutils module

locuaz.amberutils.amb_to_gmx(name: str, pdb: PDBStructure, prmtop: Union[FileHandle, Path], rst: Union[FileHandle, Path], *, target_chains: Iterable[str], binder_chains: Iterable[str]) → Tuple[GROStructure, ZipTopology][source]
locuaz.amberutils.chunk(f: TextIO) → Generator[source]
locuaz.amberutils.create_tleap_script(local_dir: Union[DirHandle, Path], name: str) → FileHandle[source]
locuaz.amberutils.fix_pdb(in_pdb: Union[PDBStructure, Path], out_pdb_path: Path) → PDBStructure[source]
locuaz.amberutils.fixup_top(top_path: Path, name: str, *, target_chains: Iterable[str], binder_chains: Iterable[str]) → FileHandle[source]
locuaz.amberutils.get_posres_include(mol_name: str, target_chains: Iterable[str], binder_chains: Iterable[str]) → str[source]
locuaz.amberutils.run_acpype(name: str, prmtop: Union[FileHandle, Path], rst: Union[FileHandle, Path], *, target_chains: Iterable, binder_chains: Iterable) → Tuple[GROStructure, ZipTopology][source]
locuaz.amberutils.run_tleap(tleap_script: Union[FileHandle, Path], name: str) → Tuple[PDBStructure, FileHandle, FileHandle][source]

runs tleap script and then uses a local PDB to add chainID info to the .prmtop and box info to the .rst7. Then it uses both to overwrite the PDB to keep everything in sync (in case, for example, that the tleap script added ions)

Parameters

  • tleap_script (Union[FileHandle, Path]) – script that loads a local PDB and outputs a .prmtop and a .rst7 file

  • name (str) – name of the system

Returns

.pdb, .prmtop and .rst7 – The .prmtop and the .rst7 are the output of the tleap script, and both are read by parmed to generate the .pdb.

Return type

Tuple[PDBStructure, FileHandle, FileHandle]

locuaz.cli module

locuaz.cli.check_sites_mmpbsa(config: Dict) → None[source]
locuaz.cli.get_dir_size(folder: Path) → float[source]
locuaz.cli.get_memory(config: Dict) → Tuple[Set, List[List]][source]

get_memory() compares character by character of the branch folders resnames to find differences among them that would correspond to previously done mutations. Small issue in this function: when an epoch was generated from more than 1 top branch, the mutations performed on that epoch will be memorized and also the ones that were actually performed on a previous epoch and were already present, since it will find differences among them.

One could remove positions that are repeated in more than 1 memory slot, but it’s impossible to know if the cause of this was the aforementioned example, or, a previous run with a shorter memory (or no memory at all), that mutated the same position more than once in the last N (N being equal to config[“protocol”][“memory_size”]) epochs. Hence, no overlap is removed and repetitive resSeqs may be found on the resulting List of Lists.

Sets: config[“misc”][“epoch_mutated_positions”] and config[“protocol”][“memory_positions”],

Parameters

config (Dict) – input config options from the user.

Returns

resSeqs where different AAs where found. It may be empty, when the branch folders being proved don’t have the same number of chains and the same length of residues being mutated.

Return type

List[List[int]]

locuaz.cli.get_ngpus()[source]
locuaz.cli.get_raw_config(config_path: str)[source]
locuaz.cli.get_tracking_files(config: Dict) → bool[source]

get_valid_branch_dirs(): filters out paths in input and returns valid branch paths

  • config (dict) – input config.

Returns

list of valid branch names

Return type

List[str]

locuaz.cli.is_not_epoch_0(branches: Union[List[str], List[Path]], starting_epoch: int)[source]
locuaz.cli.lacks_branches(current_branches: Union[List[str], List[Path]], top_branches: Union[List[str], List[Path]], config: Dict[str, Any]) → bool[source]

Checks the integrity of the current epoch. This prevents restart errors after the protocol was interrupted during the initialization of new epochs, due to missing branches or incomplete branches (branch wasn’t fully initialized).

Parameters

  • current_branches (Union[List[str], List[Path]]) – branches to be checked.

  • top_branches (Union[List[str], List[Path]]) – used to determine the number of branches there should be in the current epoch. If config["protocol"]["constant_width"] = True, then the number of branches in the current epoch is just config["protocol"]["new_branches"], if not, then ‘new_branches’ has to be multiplied by the number of top branches from the previous epoch.

  • config (Dict[str, Any]) – user input config file.

Returns

lacks_branches – indicates whether there are missing branches or not.

Return type

bool

locuaz.cli.main() → Tuple[Dict, bool][source]

Console script for locuaz.

locuaz.fixbox module

locuaz.fixbox.fix_box(uni: Universe, *, target_indices: Iterable, binder_indices: Iterable, non_protein_indices: Iterable) → Tuple[bool, Universe][source]

fix_box() wraps the atoms of a system around its box and then centers them. From: Baptista, A. M.; da Rocha, L.; Campos, S. R. R. FixBox: A General Algorithm to Fix Molecular Systems in Periodic Boxes. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2022, 62 (18), 4435–4447. https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jcim.2c00823.

Parameters

  • uni (mda.Universe) –

  • target_indices (Iterable) –

  • binder_indices (Iterable) –

  • non_protein_indices (Iterable) –

Returns

boolean indicating whether there are target or

binder atoms outside the box and the universe with the wrapped coords.

Return type

Tuple[bool, mda.Universe]

locuaz.fixbox.fix_box_cpx(cpx: GROComplex, out_path: Path, gmx_bin: str = 'gmx') → Tuple[bool, PDBStructure][source]

fix_box_cpx(): fix_box() wrapper for the protocol. :param cpx: GROComplex :type cpx: GROComplex :param out_path: output PDB :type out_path: Path :param gmx_bin: GROMACS binary executable name :type gmx_bin: str

Returns

boolean indicating whether there are target or

binder atoms outside the box and PDBStructure of the input out_path.

Return type

Tuple[bool, PDBStructure]

locuaz.fixbox.get_matrix(dimensions)[source]

locuaz.gromacsutils module

locuaz.gromacsutils.fix_gromacs_pdb(pdb_in_fn: Path, pdb_out_fn: Path, *, new_chainID: Optional[str] = None, allowed_nonstandard_residues: Optional[Set] = None) → Path[source]

uses Bio to add TER between chains, END at the end, and manually make the resSeq numbers continuous. Since this changes the PBD numbering it should only be used for structures to be used for scoring. For ex., Haddock requires chains to have unique resSeq numbers.

Parameters

  • pdb_in_fn (Path) – input PDB

  • pdb_out_fn (Path) – output PDB

  • new_chainID (Optional[str]) – For assigning a new chain ID to all atoms in the output PDB

  • allowed_nonstandard_residues (Optional[set]) – Any residue not present in AA_MAP or in this set will be discarded from the output PDB. Useful when scoring complexes with ligands.

Returns

the output PDB – the PDB will be written with Biopython’s PDB tools.

Return type

Path

locuaz.gromacsutils.image_traj(cpx: GROComplex, out_trj_fn: Path, use_tleap: bool = False, gmx_bin: str = 'gmx') → XtcTrajectory[source]
locuaz.gromacsutils.remove_overlapping_solvent(overlapped_pdb: PDBStructure, overlapped_resSeq: int, nonoverlapped_out_pdb: Path, log: Logger, *, cutoff: float = 3, use_tleap=False) → PDBStructure[source]

remove_overlapping_solvent() is overlapped with later stages. It may leave a system without ions, but not in a state that would imply discontinuity between ions and solvent, when ions are added on a later step. Thus, it removes all ions, relying on later steps (the building of Complex) to add them if necessary.

locuaz.gromacsutils.remove_overlapping_waters(complex: GROComplex, config: Dict, overlapped_resSeq: int) → GROComplex[source]

DEPRECATED remove_overlapping_waters takes a complex and removes all the waters that are within a certain cutoff from overlapped_resSeq. Then it replaces them. It does a lot of gymnastics to deal with Gromacs weirdness.

Parameters

  • config (Dict) – work project’s config file

  • complex (AbstractComplex) – a Gromacs complex

  • overlapped_resSeq (int) – assumes that this residue belongs to ‘binder’

Returns

fully loaded complex with no overlaps between water and overlapped_resSeq

Return type

AbstractComplex

locuaz.gromacsutils.write_non_overlapping_ndx(pdb_path: Path, ndx_fn_in: FileHandle, resSeq: int, *, dist_threshold: float = 0.3, gmx_bin: str = 'gmx') → Tuple[FileHandle, int][source]

locuaz.interface module

locuaz.interface.get_freesasa_residues(pdb_input: Union[PDBStructure, FileHandle, Path], chainIDs: List[str]) → Set[int][source]
locuaz.interface.get_interface_surface(pdb_path: Path, i: Optional[int] = None) → Tuple[int, Optional[float]][source]

get_interface_surface(): i could be the index of the input PBD, in case the function is called on a concurrent manner and order is needed when populating an array :param pdb_path: input PDB :param i: optional index of the input PBD, it’ll be returned as is. Useful in case the function is called on a concurrent manner and order is needed when populating an array

Returns

Tuple[int, float] = i, surface in A^2

locuaz.interface.get_interfacing_residues(pdb_input: Union[PDBStructure, FileHandle, Path], chainIDs: List[str], probe_radius: float = 1.4, amber_numbering: bool = False) → Set[int][source]

get_interfacing_residues(): use freesasa to get the resSeq of the binder residues that are in contact with the target. These can be used to guide the 2choice of the next mutated position. :param pdb_input: input PDB. :type pdb_input: Union[PDBStructure, FileHandle, Path] :param chainIDs: only residues belonging to these chains will be reported. :type chainIDs: List[str] :param probe_radius: probe_radius for freesasa :param amber_numbering: if True, it will renumber the resSeqs of the input PDB (on another temporary PDB) :type amber_numbering: bool :param as per Amber numbering scheme: :param that is: :param continuous resSeq numbers as opposed to GROMACS numbering: :param which starts at 1 on each chain.:

Returns

set of resSeqs from the binder that lie on the interface

Return type

Set[int]

locuaz.moleculesutils module

locuaz.moleculesutils.fix_wat_naming(pdb_in: Union[PDBStructure, Path], pdb_out: Path, *, use_tleap: bool = False) → PDBStructure[source]
locuaz.moleculesutils.get_gro_ziptop_from_pdb(*, pdb: PDBStructure, target_chains: Iterable, binder_chains: Iterable, md_config: Dict, add_ions: bool = False) → Tuple[PDBStructure, GROStructure, ZipTopology][source]

Does a pdb2gmx from the PDB and tries to keep the system neutral, which may alter the topology so a new PDB will be written with the same name as the original, which will be backed up by GROMACS. No ‘editconf’ or ‘solvate’ is run. The system is assumed to have solvent and a CRYST1 record with box info.

Parameters

  • pdb (PDBStructure) – input PDB

  • target_chains (Iterable) – target chainIDs. Will be used to construct the ZipTopology

  • binder_chains (Iterable) – binder chainIDs. Will be used to construct the ZipTopology

  • md_config (Dict) – user’s config input for MD

  • add_ions – whether to neutralize with genion or not. Useful after a mutation was done on the input PDB.

Returns

pdb, gro, ziptop – Proper, nice, system.

Return type

Tuple[PDBStructure, GROStructure, ZipTopology]

locuaz.moleculesutils.get_gro_ziptop_from_pdb_tleap(*, pdb: PDBStructure, target_chains: Iterable, binder_chains: Iterable) → Tuple[PDBStructure, GROStructure, ZipTopology][source]
Parameters

  • pdb (PDBStructure) – input PDB

  • target_chains (Iterable) – target chainIDs. Will be used to construct the ZipTopology

  • binder_chains (Iterable) – binder chainIDs. Will be used to construct the ZipTopology

Returns

pdb, gro, ziptop – Proper, nice, system.

Return type

Tuple[PDBStructure, GROStructure, ZipTopology]

Bases: Exception

class locuaz.primitives.PriorityDeque(maxsize: int)[source]

Bases: Generic[T], Sequence, Iterable

PriorityDeque is a fixed-size Priority queue, unless the input maxsize is negative in which case it has not size limit. I tried to implement it using heappush, heappop and heappushpop, but it uses a weird ordering, and it forces the element type to be comparable as well, to decide between pairs that have the same priorities. In this class, that’s left to bisect, since we don’t care about sorting stability.

get() → Tuple[int, T][source]
put(pair: Tuple[int, T]) → None[source]
exception locuaz.primitives.UserInputError[source]

Bases: Exception

locuaz.validatore module

class locuaz.validatore.Validatore(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Bases: Validator

Validator class. Normalizes and/or validates any mapping against a validation-schema which is provided as an argument at class instantiation or upon calling the validate(), validated() or normalized() method. An instance itself is callable and executes a validation.

All instantiation parameters are optional.

There are the introspective properties types, validators, coercers, default_setters, rules, normalization_rules and validation_rules.

The attributes reflecting the available rules are assembled considering constraints that are defined in the docstrings of rules’ methods and is effectively used as validation schema for schema.

Parameters

  • schema (any mapping) – See schema. Defaults to None.

  • ignore_none_values (bool) – See ignore_none_values. Defaults to False.

  • allow_unknown (bool or any mapping) – See allow_unknown. Defaults to False.

  • require_all (bool) – See require_all. Defaults to False.

  • purge_unknown (bool) – See purge_unknown. Defaults to to False.

  • purge_readonly (bool) – Removes all fields that are defined as readonly in the normalization phase.

  • error_handler (class or instance based on BaseErrorHandler or tuple) – The error handler that formats the result of errors. When given as two-value tuple with an error-handler class and a dictionary, the latter is passed to the initialization of the error handler. Default: BasicErrorHandler.

checkers = ()
coercers = ()
default_setters = ()
